Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Anything harsh or derogatory regarding someone's identity, such as their looks, race, gender, or sexual orientation, is considered an identity attack.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Citing recent academic research, the unclassified documents note extreme right-wing and white supremacist ideology has been the “main ideological source” for 17 per cent of so-called lone wolf attacks worldwide.

Comment: Traffic Safety historically consisted of three "legs" -  Education, Engineering and Enforcement.  The first is fuzzy but very essential, the second generates the need for the first and responds to the failure of both the first and third.  A stool with one leg?  Photo radar is a slam dunk for #1 and #3. Folks don't want to be held personally accountable so it's a dim prospect.  The education part can play a huge part; I had cut through neighbors that never gave a thought to the impact they had going to a from home until it was pointed out at a community event.  The "Slow Down Snowmen" can be effective as can the "Drive Like You Live Here" posters.  Each can reach someone and make a difference, none can reach all.  It's significant to keep history in where we are today - in the '80s a particular 3 Way Stop came to be when the "Warrant" said No but a citizen convinced the Traffic Engineer otherwise.  The Warrant process was right but the toolbox was empty save a hammer.

Comment: The point is not the inflation adjustment in the future - the point is that typically the civil service wage is a lot higher than what the same job pays in the private sector.  The disparity gets even wider when benefits and (especially) pensions are considered.  A 3-year freeze, for example, is not even a very severe measure when you start out 25% ahead.  That might let the private workers close up, say, one quarter of the gap.  So I will shed no tears for the union head.
It is true, however, that the managerial ranks, especially in the medical area, are even more overpaid than the rank-and-file union staff.  So how about a "progressive" pay cut?  15% above $200k, zero at $40k, and a sliding scale in between.  The more you make, the bigger the (%) cut.   That would preserve as much as possible of spending and jobs, while seriously denting the budget deficit.

Comment: Beware the man who offers you HIS position as a "compromise" between his position and your position.

No one was pro-slavery. No one encouraged slavery. The issue was merely, Are slave-owners moral agents or not?

The so-called "abolitionists" did not recognize slave-owners as moral agents, with the God-given faculty of Free Will. Thus, the "abolitionists" were attacking a basic tenet of Chritianity: that man is created in the image and likeness of God--i.e., possessing intellect and will.

The "abolitionists" sought to establish a theocracy, in which the moral agency of slave-owners would be trampled, replaced by a robotic adherence to the dictates of "an ecumenism of evil," seeking to school former slaves in the "prosperity gospel" by allowing them to work for themselves.

Comment: "And attempting to modify the 2nd will be about as effective as the existing thousands of gun control laws..."
I disagree. Change the Amendment to (something like) rifles are restricted to hunting and contain no more than 3 rounds and no clip. Handguns are revolvers only and restricted to one ownership per person. Anyone caught with a non-compliant weapon is immediately sent to prison and prohibited from owning any gun for any reason.
Call me whatever name feels right, but I've owned guns and probably shot several thousand rounds, so I understand how much fun they can be. I'm also willing to acknowledge that a semi-automatic rifle with a detachable clip is good for one thing only: killing. Any hunter who needs more than three bullets should stop hunting. Competition shooting is fun, but what's the point of marksmanship with a weapon designed to kill?
I'm not a liberal, I'm not a Democrat, I'm not a gun-grabber - I'm sick of people standing on an Amendment to justify weapons that kill.

Comment: Another thing to do is to develop a somewhat thickened skin and let it roll off.....

When I was in college, my three best friends all died in a plane wreck. As it happened, one of the engineering professors that I had in the trimester immediately following was an aviation enthusiast. He loved to make wise cracks about planes crashing (I think the class was engineering dynamics), and you wanna talk about "triggers"? It was all I could do to hold it together some days. I thought about approaching him privately to tell him my situation and to ask him to hold back on those jokes, but I realized it was my problem, nothing was going to bring my buddies back, and I'd have to get used to it. It never would have occurred to me to report him to some committee for making hurtful comments.

A pox on all these wimpy kids who need protection from life... and may the fleas of a thousand camels infest the armpits of those who promote such "solutions".

Comment: If what you say is true, then that would mean that judges who are of the same mind, shouldn't bother with what the law says as written and the context under which it was intended. For example, "unauthorized entry into a motor vehicle" law was originally intended to address car theft. For whatever reason, it then was the administrative states decision to use that same law to try someone who say, punches someone through a car window. Not enough evidence for an "assault" charge? No prob. "Unauthorized entry into a motor vehicle". Am I a purist? No. But pretty close. If judges are allowed to interpret the laws not by original intent nor by what is written, then why need legislators?  Isn't that abrogating the legislative branch?  You usually bring up separation of powers and co-equal branches, why not in this instance? If the judicial branch can override the legislative, then you also support overriding the executive which in the past you have commented about. Why have elections?

Comment: I lived in a small home town with virtually no fences.    It's a very close community, a fence was almost an affront to the city's sensibility.    Neighbors watched out for each others homes (some was snooping, but you weren't going to be dead three days before somebody found the body either).

One style is not better than the other.   We have to basic civil behaviors to keep the community thriving,    I believe in some recognizable standards in any community.   If one chooses to not live in  a close community, there are other options.

I'm a big believer in the power of teams.   They are more likely to take risk than are individuals, which seems an oxymoron, but a team also provided shared results, good and bad.     Many people simply function better in a team atmosphere.

Cleary a 'team' doesn't have to be giant federal bureaucracy, but interconnection has been critical for success throughout human history.  So are stories of great individual accomplishments within a team structure.

Comment: It is true both that:

1. Each country has ongoing interests and these should not be unduly confused with its values and friends;

2. It serves no good purpose for the senior political figures of one country to gratuitously criticize the policies and actions of another country.

However, it does not follow that international observance and support for the deepest values of one's country is not itself an ongoing national interest.  Nor is it true that to remain passive and silent when such a deeply held value is violated best furthers the ongoing interests of one's country.

There is an appropriate way in each circumstance where our country's deep, enduring interests are being degraded by others (as, arguably, they have been over the past week for Canada's) for our PM to express Canada's concerns. Trudeau has so acted.

BTW, Canada hasn't and shouldn't distance itself from Mexico on the basic point that NAFTA can't function if based upon bullying.

Comment: All this junk about "not timing" the market and the virtues of passive investing only make sense in a secular bull market. Had you passively invested in the 1920s, you would have had pretty close to a 0% return until 1950.

Market cycles matter, and timing those is incredibly important. The conventional wisdom surrounding passive investment makes me think back to the old conventional wisdom in the US (and the current conventional wisdom here in Canada!) about housing. Just because something has worked well for the past 20 years does not mean you should blindly repeat it for the next 20 years and expect similar results.

Comment: With respect to TFSA, time is of the essence. This year, I maxed out my TFSA on January 3, and invested 7100 dollars back into a high dividend yield Canadian ETF. How did I go above the 5500 limit? Easy. Dividends throughout last year. We had about 1500 in dividends last year in the TFSA. As I get the dividends, I dump them in TD e-series index funds. Then in January, I sell the index funds and re-invest them in a high yield Canadian ETF. 

Be patient. Over time, that 5500 contriubtion limit for the TFSA will mean nothing as you re-invest your dividends.

Comment: The mature view is that the US, on the one hand, and Mexico and Canada, on the other, benefit from NAFTA and would benefit further from updates reflecting the needs of economies that have evolved over the past 3 decades. Likewise, all would suffer a brutal transition and loss of many long term benefits if NAFTA was terminated.

These will be tough negotiations and may be punctuated by one side or the other suspending negotiations or threatening to terminate NAFTA.  However, there are good reasons to believe that after prolonged negotiations a viable compromise solution will emerge.

The key is for Canada and Mexico to remain steadfast and reasonable and not allow themselves to become overawed or bullied into accepting unreasonable concessions to the US or into foregoing reasonable US concessions as part of the final bargain.

Comment: "People die soon enough without help."  I'm sorry, but I have to disagree with you.  My dad was 82 years old when he had most of his stomach removed because of cancer.  He could not eat any food or drink liquids through his mouth for 2 years until he passed.  He was fed with a tube through his nose.  We could only dab his lips to keep it moist.  He went from 160 pounds to 80 pounds.  His skin was dry and shriveled.  When we touched his skin to change his diaper or to give him a sponge bath,  some would tear off and bleed.  To hear him cry in pain was horrible.  Though bedridden, he could still talk to us and watch TV, but, we had to be careful in moving him from position to position so we don't tear more skin.  If you call this living, well...  I hope you don't get cancer or any other illness where you have to suffer like my dad did.  Can you live without eating food or drinking anything for years?   I don't want to go through what he went through.  MY body, MY life, MY choice.

Comment: I think too many people look at the Bible as a means to feign intellectual prowess, to show off some LITTLE linguistic factoid they heard or read about on the internet, to demonstrate how smart they are. 

Vanity drives a lot of this behavior.

The Bible is about a love affair.  God's love affair with us. 

There's an element to it that may require serious study, the application of knowledge of ancient languages and so forth.

But for most of us, we have to be honest...we're not going to be true scholars of the Bible...real scholars, no, REAL scholars who can do independent research & - crucially - useful synthesis.

For the rest of us, the Bible should help us more in the spiritual and interior realm of our life with God.

It should help us to know God, Jesus Christ, & His love for us.
It should help us pray better, more sincerely, like a child.
It should help us love like Jesus.
It should help us make resolutions to be a better husband or wife, parent.
It should help us work better.

Comment: As Michael loves Pipe Organs, let me pull out a minor stop here in the conversation, perhaps a 4 foot flute (sorry to all who don't get the organ analogy)  The minor point is, of course, that there is no credible evidence that Jesus was born on December 25th to begin with. Clement of Rome pegged it for some time in November (Jesus was a Scorpio!) Hippolytus didn't have a particular date, but he was sure it was a Wednesday.  Shepherds would not have been in the field with their flocks in the middle of winter (it snows in Israel during the winter,) and pilgrims would not have made the trek to complete the supposed census in the harsh conditions of winter.  Some contemporary scholars suggest September, based on the supposed date of John's birth, etc.  Point is, Christmas is a bit of a historical mystery, but I guess that doesn't matter to those who want life time-warped back to the 1950's.  So it might be more apt to say Happy Saturnalia, since that was the holiday it supplanted.

Comment: The USA has a miserable average savings rate. Touting HSAs to people who already don't save doesn't get us anywhere. People who want savings accounts to dip into for routine medical expenses probably already have them.
Yes, there's an argument to be made that health insurance shouldn't cover garden-variety expenses, but even with my mid-level Medicare supplement plan, I pay a co-pay for office visits, my co-pay for specialist visits or some diagnostic tests is much higher, and most of my generic prescription drugs cost less than my maximum co-pay. So I feel my out-of-pocket expenses don't qualify as a free ride.
And I fail to see how buying health insurance from Mutual of New Jersey, when I live in Denver, benefits me. Talking to a call-center doctor in Newark is a helluva way to fix a broken leg.

Comment: Dennis, thanks for that.  I know I sound as if I thought little of "Tradition".  That is not true, but I do think we have to learn to adapt Tradition to new circumstances.  

I also think the insistence that there are no flaws in the teachings because the Holy Spirit is always with us is a distortion of God's willingness to let men have free will.  The Holy Spirit can nudge and guide, but ultimately it is human beings who make decisions and not all those human choices are exactly what God would have wished.  This applies even to Popes, to synods and councils of the Church, to bishops and priests as well as to the non-clerical world.  

We need leadership.  We need the wisdom of people learned and practiced in our faith.  But we really need to also learn to trust ourselves and to let those learned and wise people be our guides always realizing that they are not God Himself, but good educated and wise humans who try to understand what is good and right.

Comment: Yes I saw that, but I have the additional understanding to recognize that analysis is logically subsumed under Opinion (what they call Op Ed in the business). An op ed is an editorial that is not produced by a newspaper's Editorial Board or any other staff member and is not a news report. The op refers to the fact that it was traditionally published on the opposite page of the papers Editorials and Letters to the Editor.  In doing so, it is recognized that there are no clear lines between analysis and opinion.

Just as I had the additional reading comprehension to recognize that when the author of the Op Ed writes "Looking at coastal flood and storm-surge protection" when starting a paragraph, he is talking about the Texas coast in general not Houston specifically. The paragraph break between land use planning and Houston and the clearly differentiated paragraph about the coastal area was another clue.  Somehow you seem to forget that areas such as Rockport were badly damaged.

Comment: Why do women have to pay for prostate cancer or testicular cancer? 
Why do men have to pay for ovarian cancer or uterine cancer?

Because it's best to consolidate the health care system into one big risk pool for the entire population.

Having several different pools -- one for men, one for women, "one for the poor, another for the aged, another for employees of this or that company -- blocks the cross-subsidization from the rich to the poor, the young to the old and the healthy to the sick upon which insurance relies. It makes it tougher to control costs, as doctors and hospitals facing a cost-control squeeze in one pool might simply charge more to patients or insurers in the other."

Comment: First off, the unit of energy is the Watt-Hour, KW-Hour, or in other words power times time.  Mr. Jepson mistakes Watts, which is power per unit time, for energy.

Second, Mr. Jepson entirely ignores the variability of his proposed wind and solar farms.  Clearly solar is dead at night.  Wind comes and goes.  Without addressing the variability issue, proponents cannot be taken seriously.

Of course hydropower, which is short term stable is an incredible, wonderful source of renewable energy.  It also is driven by the sun which evaporates water which is then dropped at high elevations allowing its energy on the way back to the see to be harvested.  We should have water wheels along the rivers and streams.  No flow blockage.  Reliable energy.

Solar and wind can only play a major role if the variability problem is addressed.  I wish folks like Mr. Jepson would get serious.  I am concerned that he is teaching at UO.

Comment: Regarding: "The bishops and clergy of the Catholic Church must, repeat must, engage in sustained preaching and catechesis on the Church’s teaching about migrants."
- Were that this is done without confusion.
- A migrant is a person in transit (farm workers, travelers, academics are examples of this). An immigrant is someone who has come to stay. Refugees can become immigrants, or they could return to their nation of origin at a later time. Asylum seekers are in effect seeking permanent residency outside the usual channels of immigration establish by US law.
- Fairly, both groups have a right to justice and dignity.
- The issue is, and the hierarchy of the church state this, that the civil laws are to be respected, that is, not ignored.
- So, at minimum, the clergy of the Catholic Church should be ensuring that those being deported are not abused, or bereft of the law, and that the clergy of the Catholic Church of the receiving countries are ready to aid those returning.

Comment: As On-Line Reader suggests, burn-out can sneak up on you.  Often, you're too frazzled to notice, and--like me--may actually deny that you're making far more job-related mistakes than you did not long before. 

Sometimes it takes an external nudge to step off and, as John Lennon once told me, sit there, "watching the wheels go 'round and 'round."  B.C.'s late-90s recession gave me the nudge.  Another hint: by accident met a radio station sales mgr friend at a Tim Hortons. As he got out of his car, he saw me, threw his hands in the air and shouted, "Where IS everybody??"

A few months in, I was out.  Sold everything. Packed up and (like the Wild Bunch,  Shawshank Redemption pals, and countless others) crossed the border to Mexico. If you're gonna change it up, well...

The single best move I ever made. Life-changing in more ways than I the word-count to tell. All good, even when bad (and, baby, in Mexico it can get bad!) Never regretted it.  

So take heart.  And change it up.

Comment: We understand PERS negotiated impacts now.  But let's go back to how it all started.  In the last few years of last Century, public employees needed wage increases as theirs were flat.  Even with low rates of inflation, they lost ground.  Our past state leaders kicked the can down the road.  Given a choice between "Pay Me Now" (which came out of current budgets) or "Pay Me Later" - they chose later.  PERS eligible employees agreed and a contract was signed.  I watched in horror and asked, "Don't our legislators understand compounding"?  

But in the go go 90's, where 10% was a low return on your portfolio and savings accounts still paid 5% interest, what could change.  Now the can is the size of Everest and you can hit it with a bomb and nothing happens.

So whose contract do you plan to break - and if you do who can negotiate anything with the state?   Perhaps we need Presidential leadership on this.  I can see him personally convening death panels.

Comment: KGB hasn't existed since the Soviet Union disbanded, so I doubt they were involved in this.
"Somehow all of the Russian cheating just happened spontaneously."
Doping in sports isn't spontaneous, its ubiquitous. That's not a rationalizing statement, it's matter of fact. It isn't a new phenomenon, or even a phenomenon. Increasing dopamine enhances brain and body performance, healing, and development, and so increasing the body's ability to do all of those things is a basic part of professions dependent upon those things.
The media is sensationalizing the issue for political purposes, because the public isn't familiar with the reality, allowing for easy manipulative sematicizing of the term "doping," just like WADA doesn't consider doping that is done by prescription (as Western nations handle it) as doping. Doping is doping, and its a pillar of professional sport, just as dopamine is the cornerstone of human brain functionality and health.
Guess what: the "War on Drugs" is fiction, too.

Comment: Nice lopsided bunch of letters, telling the reader everything wrong with vouchers, as they see it. Lots of attacks on vouchers, but no understanding of how they work. Say a district has 10,000 students and it is determined that it will take $6,000 to teach each student. That should mean that each school in the district should get $6,000 per pupil to educate the students. No one believes that will be enough and no one believes that voucher money will be for 100% of the required amount. So, if a family gets even $5,000 in voucher money, they will have to make up the rest and the private school will have to fund whatever else it takes to educate each pupil. So, if there are 10,000 students and adequate space in both public and private schools to educate all the students, and if vouchers are given to property tax paying families to use educate their kids, how is that using establishing a religion if the voucher goes to a church run private school.

Comment: This just reflects changes in the humanities themselves. There is nothing called "humanity" any more in the "humanities." The very word is archaic--not to mention the concept. Contemporary study in the "humanities" holds that there is nothing called the "human." The human is a kind of religious vestige, a universalist fantasy that is itself ideological and foisted on groups and inculcated in individuals, often to their disadvantage.The humanities now study the ways human animals are essentially different and divided from each other into various kinds of groups with power distributed asymmetrically among the groups. The arts and histories and even the sciences these groups produce either reproduce and strengthen these asymmetries or expose and oppose them.  And there is no "truth" or "philosophy." There is only the sociology of knowledge. So the decline in the humanities is not a decline in enrollments to be addressed with better marketing. It is an outcome of the humanities themslves.

Comment: "It is the mark of an intelligent mind to be able to entertain an idea without accepting it."

It's the mark of an aggressively unintelligent mind to spout platitudes without considering whether they're applicable.  Your obvious assumption here is that this is the first time CherryCreekCrab has been presented with this idea.  The reason we don't "entertain" flat earth ideas is that they have been floated (as the article points out) since antiquity.  In the last several thousand years, these ideas have not evolved at all, and have only gotten easier and easier to debunk as technology has allowed us to travel around the globe, view detailed maps created via satellites, use handheld devices that pinpoint our locations, and on and on.  We can also just rely on common sense and note how quickly objects disappear over the horizon.

An intelligent mind entertains an idea until it's blatantly disproved, and then stops wasting time on it, regardless of how many idiots try to bring it up again.

Comment: A law to "make it clear that an unconscious person cannot consent to sexual activity" is utterly redundant; no court or sane lawyer has ever questioned that. Obviously, by definition of unconsciousness, an unconscious person is incapable of giving or refusing consent.

There is a related and more difficult question. Can a person, while conscious, give advance consent to sexual activity while unconscious? The Supreme Court of Canada has answered that question in the negative, and by doing so has potentially opened a serious can of worms. Many people in established relationships enjoy being awakened by their partner's intimate touch; however, as it stands any such touch constitutes an assault. You may have been married and sleeping together for years while enjoying an active and varied sex life, but if you touch your sleeping bed partner for a sexual purpose you are committing sexual assault. I think that law needs to be changed to make it clear that advance consent is good consent.

Comment: There is nothing unfair about how taxes and fees are assessed against motor vehicles. With or without bicycles, pedestrians, or equestrians, you would be paying to register it annually and for fuel taxes. It is a government revenue stream that existed well before the growth of cycling for recreation and transportation. As the primary user and contributor to wear and tear, being on the hook for additional costs to use roads that are funded by the general fund is quite fair. 

If you think cyclists get off scott free, we'll be awful excited to learn we don't pay sales or property taxes. Heck, if I do the math, a car that gets 20mpg over the course of a 12,000 mile year will pay $132 in fuel taxes, which is right about the same amount of state sales tax that is collected on a mid to high end bike. Given the amount of thriving bike shops in the metro area, the cycling community is contributing plenty towards their use of roads and trails.

Comment: Been to the following European cities in the past 10 years: London, Copenhagen, Malmo, Tampere, Vienna, Innsbrook, Salzburg, Moscow, St. Petersburg, Zurich, Minsk, Yaroslavl , Helsinki, Frankfurt, Vaxjo. So, what I've noticed is that Europe is a lot older than Canada. 
Having just returned from Copenhagen its refreshing to see all the bikes and the mass of bikes that are parked. Yes there are many dedicated bike lanes, but what stuck out more than anything was the respect drivers had for cyclists. Plus, people ride their bikes in Europe because its what they can afford. And the distances they cover are much less than what we cover in the GTA. 
It drives me nuts when people compare Europe to Canada. Here in the GTA it's a mini war between pedestrians and cyclists and the car/truck. I've never felt that way in Europe. In fact it's the opposite. 
To change attitudes for cyclists and the car will take another 25 years .

Comment: "Its funny because only one of those is a District Policy most are superintendent a superintendent Delegate policy level decision I see only one (actually voted on in the last 2 months) that specifies US history at the board level."

This makes no sense.

Why are these courses listed as graduation requirements if they aren't really required by the district to graduate?  

Here's what I know.....at my current school (and the other ones at which I have taught), if students don't take and pass a year of US History and a semester of American Government (along with 2 semesters of Social Studies electives), they don't graduate--plain and simple.  At the district in CO where I worked, 4 full years were required.  No pass, no graduation.

I understand that the State only requires a half-credit of Civics.  School districts set their own policies and requirements (often guided by what colleges require for entry), and are free to do so, so long as state requirements are met.

Comment: Both spellings are acceptable in this country as is colour.  In fact, that is the way I learned to spell things is US Army schools as a dependent - oh yes, also neighbour.  The real reason the "u" was dropped was for newspapers (same reason for second "e" in employee).  They looked everywhere for ways to save type (bake in the days of hot metal type) and bastardized the language in the process.  So, it's not so much "American" spelling as Chicago Tribune, New York Herald, etc. spelling that was simply adopted because no one really cared all that much.

Comment: I have yet to see a "compostable bag" that is actually compostable.  Just because some company figured out that they can call it "compostable" because it will break down at 85C after two months does not mean it will break down either in your backyard or in the vast, vast, majority of composters run by even large Canadian municipalities.

If you're super serious about this stuff, call your municipality and ask first before buying them to avoid throwing your money away for no reason. But if you're super serious about making a difference, there are a dozen ways to make a bigger difference and they all involve not even using plasticish bags in the first place.

Comment: TELUS is a good company and John Heinzl has presented it well.  Now why not do the same for Bell and Rogers.  I bought Bell before it split in April 1997.  It split again in May 2000 and I sold it in 2002.  I made a lot of money over the years with steady dividends.  I don't know if there was a TELUS back then.  I bought back in to BCE in 2014 for $48 each.  I had a number in DRIP programs particularly in four Canadian Banks.  With DRIPs back then the companies' Trusts wanted you to hold the actual shares.  They were pretty and I had filing cabinet full.  Also an investor had to calculate the annual dividend and include it in your tax return each year.  Brokers were reluctant to do any of this for you.   One broker said on TV that she didn't recommend drips because she didn't make any money from them.
There are only four telecom stocks in the TSX sector and I choose to hold BCE.  I have to spread money around for diversification in multiple accounts.

Comment: I actually don't care which level of government handles health care but it should be either completely federal or completely provincial.  When you have it handled by both it leads to inefficiency due to overlap and reduces accountability is each side tries to blame the other.  At least if done by one level you know who to hold accountable if things go wrong.  As for inequality, I think what is important is we keep equality of opportunity, equality of outcome is not needed.  On income inequality Canada is a bit below the OECD average but on economic mobility we are third behind Denmark and Finland while ahead of Sweden and Norway and it's income mobility not income equality that matters.  First is outcome latter is opportunity.

Comment: Roland, the risk that I was referring to is the financial risk associated with receiving the annual utility savings vs. the market volatility of an investment that generates a net after-tax return of 4.6% annually.  Forget your 6%, that's just an arbitrary number.   You need to earn 4.6% in an investment that has lower risk than the utility bill savings in order for the investment option to be worthwhile.  Utility bills are paid with after-tax money, and so your investment also needs to be non-tax sheltered as well for an apples to apples. Sure, there's some risk around the Tesla warranty.  But it's relatively small.  Even if Tesla fails it doesn't mean that your roof will fail. 

Another point that I neglected is that the bill savings can be reinvested.  So, let's say I save $2500 on my elec bill during my first year.  This is an extra $2500 that I have and can put into this "6%" investment account for 30 years.  If I repeat that for years 2 through 29, then, well, you do the math...

Comment: I'm going to be clear.   This sounds like it could be adenosylcobalamin-related, in that a deficiency of adenosylcobalamin triggers expression of the gene involved.   Adenosylcobalamin plays a direct role in regulating the immune system function and plays other roles as well.

Adenosylcobalamin stores last about three years (or so) in the body, and if there is any metabolic problem from birth around it, then a logical time for issues to show up is around age three, when a deficiency will start to have a domino effect on various processes in the body.   They way, and the degree, to which this occurs would largely depend on genetics / other genetic issues.   It could be mild and it could be life-threatening as well as everything in between.

The genetic panel of tests available for metabolic and neurological issues now available in Ontario includes a number of tests that will show genetics with significant implications for adenosylcobalamin stores:  cobalamin tests, MTHFR and ABCD.

Comment: Many places have ordinances requiring buried power distribution lines in new development subdivisions with multiple lots. It's more expensive, yes, but far easier to implement at the time of construction and the costs are passed on to the new homeowner. It virtually eliminates maintenance and outages at the end point and improves the aesthetics and property valuation.

I think most people up here have come to accept that there will be at least a few notable power outages every year as a result of ice/snow, electrified squirrels, wind, fallen branches and random acts of the universe, but there's a lot of room for improvement both from a performance (maintenance cost/reliability) standpoint as well as a forward thinking development perspective.

One thing's for sure, though, Anchorage is one ugly city from a visible utility line point of view.

Comment: My father was a devout Catholic and an avowed secularist. His primary identity was Canadian. I suspect that this is the case for the vast majority of Canadians who identify with Christian religions. Their primary identity is rooted in their attachment to Canada or, as is the case for many Francophones, Quebec. More recently, however, there's been a shift as Canada has seen a growth in immigrants (and their offspring) from other religions, often from regions and/or communities where religion is synonymous with personal identity. One study, for instance, indicated that over 60 percent of Muslims in Canada identify primarily as Muslims rather than as Canadians. For many Canadians this is a troubling trend. As my now-deceased father used to note, the most positive social development he witnessed in his lifetime was the decline in sectarian religious chauvinism in the aftermath of WWII. This is a development a lot of Canadians don't want to see reversed.

Canada is projected to fall behind Australia in absolute size of economy by 2025 or so, and this is a country with less than 2/3rds Canada's population.

Comment: The principle of voluntary government financing rests on the following premises: that the government is not the owner of the citizens’ income and, therefore, cannot hold a blank check on that income—that the nature of the proper governmental services must be constitutionally defined and delimited, leaving the government no power to enlarge the scope of its services at its own arbitrary discretion.
-
 Consequently, the principle of voluntary government financing regards the government as the servant, not the ruler, of the citizens—as an agent who must be paid for his services, not as a benefactor whose services are gratuitous, who dispenses something for nothing.

Comment: I am mad that corporate propaganda has, successfully, misled the voters once again. They said,  "The money measure 97 would raise is just going to pay PERS, and not to the schools."  Well, of course it's going to pay PERS...duh!  We have contracts and obligations that must be paid and those will be paid first, before all others.  You, as a private citizen, must pay your water bill and your electric bill first, before deciding what you would like to do with your leftover money.  Your leftover money might go to cable tv or eating out, those are discretionary and you increase or decrease them as needed.  Yes, the money raised through measure 97 would have gone to pay PERS, an obligation, but it would have had left-over money for schools and seniors.  Also....if anyone cares, the tax that corporations would have paid, was to be off-set by their shareholders.  Their poor shareholders would have seen $50 less in their dividend checks next year.  Boo-hoo.

Comment: First off, the show is called "Doctor Who" not "Dr. Who." Really Caldara has it wrong. Doctor Who has always been a politically and socially driven show, so it should be no surprise that the writers would want to make this switch. Literally a season ago there was a wonderful two-part episode that dealt with an alien invasion that was in stark comparison to what radicalized terrorism looks like today. And this season, there was a story that dealt specifically with the impacts of fake news and rewriting history. Also, the show has constantly presented a diverse cast of characters with varied sexual orientation/preferences. Even in the old, old, episodes you can find obvious examples of how Doctor Who is a reflection of their generations. Hell, even the main antagonists the Daleks were created in part to reflect Nazi Germany. I suppose it is possible for this show to be enjoyed on a passive level for entertainment only, but the messages have always been there.

Comment: That claim is recited on the right all the time and flagrantly untrue. It has never happened yet. What *does* happen is: within the university there are certain areas where people can *temporarily* escape those views they are confronted with 24/7 everywhere else ON CAMPUS which dehumanizes them.
Nowhere has an entire campus been declared a safe space or treated as one.

A often conflated and entirely unrelated matter is protests against invited speakers. These are as old as time itself - for example in the 1970s there were huge protests at Harvard demanding that Milton Friedman be sacked for his association with the brutal Chilean dictator Pinochet. If anything, it is far worse to demand the firing of a tenured professor because you don't like his political activities outside of work than to say "we don't want this person to speak here". Getting to speak at a university is not a right. It's a significant honor, and people are allowed to believe somebody does not deserve that honor.

Comment: Housing used to be cheap. You would buy for cash and it included the outhouse in the back. There are still some homes like that on the Virginia Eastern Shore, but when people found out plumbing was arranged. The tax benefit is built into the price and would factor out with no subsidy. The loan also raises the price, but so does the fact that housing is better with time.

The funny thing is that more wiring was a plus. Now with WiFi it is a minus but electricity supply is still an issue. Solar panels will add price. Location is a huge price, because you buy your neighbors, or rather exclude those you don't want, with a higher price. Land Value Taxes are designed to fix that.

In the future, technology will offer habitat houses that grow food. The price of future eating will be factored in and at that point buying from an employer is essential because the interest on such dwellings would be otherwise prohibitive. Employee-owned companies building and financing houses make them doable.

Comment: My simple-minded ideas on electoral reform:

a) Keep it simple. If it takes more than two minutes to explain how it works, it is too complicated.

b) Each party in this debate is advancing the system that is most favourable to them (except the Conservatives who are hoping a referendum will reject everything and keep the existing system). So I have a hard time seeing anyone as particularly 'virtuous' in this debate.

c) People like the idea of being able to elect their own MP and kick her out if she turns out to be a bozo.

(Note the NDP's rather convoluted proposal that tries to keep ridings and MP's instead of advocating a straight forward proportional 'Party List' system which is what they are really after.)

d) God help us if we end up with a system where parties have to actually cooperate and form coalition governments as I don't think the political culture in this country is mature enough to allow that to happen on a regular basis.

Comment: The federal alcohol tax is an excise tax; it is set as a fixed amount of money per litre of absolute alcohol. A relatively small amount of tax money, federal or provincial, is generated by such taxes (the biggest one is the federal excise tax on gasoline). Most taxes are percentages, like GST or income tax. Percentage taxes automatically index; as prices and wages rise, tax revenues rise. In fact, but for bracket indexation, income taxes would increase faster than the rate of inflation due to bracket creep.

Inflation indexation of excise taxes is not a real tax increase; it just holds the tax constant in purchasing power terms.

Comment: Most of what you say is true. But to lay the blame on EVs is wrong. Today, most cobalt goes into consumer electronics:  over a billion cellphones, 500 million tablets, laptops, and PCs, and millions of cameras, power tools and other portable devices. But I see no faux outrage over that.

About 120,000 tonnes of cobalt is mined as a by-product of copper and nickel. Less than a quarter from reprehensible "artisanal" mining.  In comparison, we consume 100,000,000 barrels per DAY of oil. Vehicle air pollution causes 53,000 premature deaths each year just in the U.S. alone. The extraction, transportation, refining and ultimate burning of gasoline and diesel has a human and environmental cost that is orders of magnitude greater than from electric vehicle batteries. 

Rather than blame EVs, it would be more productive to add Cobalt to the list of "conflict" minerals and strengthen existing international sanctions.

Comment: Sorry to hear this sad news. As a young botanist and wildflower aficionado,  Verna's book was the first book I bought upon moving to Alaska in  '91. It was the best organized and most easy to use botanical guide I'd ever seen.   As a high school science teacher I used it extensively to help my budding biologists learn the native species of plants all across Alaska. As a handy field guide, I still have and use my original copy today, in addition to the other copies I bought for my classroom. My condolences go out to her family and thanks to her and her husband for their indispensable contribution to my understanding of Alaska'sal wildflowers.

Comment: Are there ANY resources that are not being depleted faster than they regenerate?   Finite resources like minerals and fossil fuels are obviously being depleted. These impacts are not evenly distributed, some places have more acute crises than others.

Our cooperative abilities that have kept us going since the days of Australopithecines are part of what would be needed to survive the enormous mess we have made.  We also have the ability to delude ourselves, to be violent and other destructive behaviors.

Techno-toys are very effective at distracting us from the depletion of the natural world.

Comment: Science defines most fit as those most likely to generate a new generation. In some situations, most natural ones in fact, that can mean "the weak" are least likely to survive, because they are poorly adapted to life's circumstances. If those circumstances change, then adaptation also changes. If a layer of benevolence is added, so that the weak are protected by the strong, some of the strong will become the poorly adapted, possibly because they are isolated from the protective society.

IOW, religion fits into the scientific theory as something that changes the environment so that it favors some over others differently than nature. The "fittest" applies to the protected who are able to reproduce more freely, rather than to the "rugged individuals" whose strength becomes less determinative.

Comment: I suggest you read the transcript of the judge's ruling. He specifically commented on the small amount of DNA evidence, and explained why it did not prove sexual activity.

"I'm just pointing out that in the case of robbery, the testimony of the complainant that the money was taken without their consent is generally sufficient."

That is incorrect. A complaint that money was stolen will certainly initiate an investigation, but if there is no corroborating evidence to show that money actually was stolen, then there will be no conviction. Otherwise people could say, "I had a hundred dollars in my wallet and now it's gone. So-and-so was the only person I can remember seeing yesterday, so obviously he took it." The police search so-and-so, but can't find any money. Questioning the complainant again, they find her recollection of the time in question was virtually nil. Comment: Over population is as devastating a problem as any in connection with the future of the world and the quality of life for everything alive, and it's one of a few that are the equivalent of asteroids hitting the planet.

However, even if a far smaller number of humans existed on the planet, they could not live as we do without destroying themselves as we have.   It would take longer, but it would happen.   In the 60s and 70s at least, and maybe the 80s, the US, all by its little self, with a tiny 5% of the world's population, was consuming around half the world's resources and producing almost half of its pollution.   We were already seeing devastating environmental effects by then.   The forests of the Sierra Nevadas were already beginning to die from beetle infestation and global warming.   

We cannot live like this and have a habitable planet.

Comment: Ranked balloting is a poor and unsatisfactory way to implement proportional representation. Much better is an approach using larger electoral districts with multiple seats (e.g. 4 to 6 varying with population size) that get allocated to the parties and to their candidates according to the votes received. That gives the voter a choice both as to party and individual and favours reasonable candidates rather than extreme partisans. That in turn makes for better cooperation among the elected members.
The biggest problem with the CPC leadership contest was that the party misused it as a recruiting tool for party members giving such grandstanders as KOL an opportunity to distort the result.

Comment: The media tends to indulge in cultivating a cult of personality around political figures to---yes---make a lot of money from election cycles.  The greatest money-maker for them is a close race, and it's fairly easy to steer public opinion by shining the spotlight on the warts and outrageous things a candidate might say to pander to certain audiences.

Our system thrives on partisan differences---It drove this election, and it'll drive the post-election transition.  It's far easier to manipulate a nominally "free" electorate when they're busy fighting each other, rather than demanding accountability from their government.  It's past time to snap out of it and learn to work together across artificial boundaries to do just that.

It's time to listen to each other, and you may as well start at home; whatever Don's warts, the Constitution has not been suspended (yet)---It's the kind of document that thrives from adversity.  We'll see how he likes it as boss.

Comment: That's not my understanding. If a cop has a legitimate reason to inquire who you are, then you must answer or risk being apprehended.

For example, maybe a robbery happened down the street and I resemble the burglar in some way. A cop may stop me and ask me to identify myself as part of the investigation into that robbery. If I refuse to answer, then I may be apprehended and held until my identity becomes known. That's what I meant by "in the course of duty."

But the cops must have a legitimate reason to inquire as to my identity. They can't just willy-nilly demand that everyone identify themselves.

Comment: The Permanent Fund was never intended to be an Individual annuity for people who simply lived here for a year.   It was meant to be a permanent annuity for the general fund so that when oil royalties were insufficient to pay for State government, the Permanent Fund earning would make up the difference.   That time is here.     5% of the fund for the general fund.   2% income tax (everyone pays), 2% sales tax.    This spreads the burden among all who live here or visit here because all who live here, or visit here, use State services and should therefore pay their fair share.   That's a sustainable plan that still makes Alaska the lowest taxed State in the Union but ensures we have good roads, schools and services, keeping Alaska a good place to work, live, and visit.

Comment: Again, the contract CPS has with SASSA prohibits them from using the recipients' information for anything other than to pay grants. That means they are not allowed to do any of this. That includes passing on information to other 'arm-length subsidiaries'. This is something they agreed to when signing the contract. 

Have you ever had to provide a cell phone company with access to your bank account and its entire history? It is what this business amounts to. A stop order is not analogous to the way money is deducted here. Stop orders are issued on a specific day every month. Not the moment you receive payment. It is very possible to transfer or spend money before a stop order is issued so that there is risk of nonpayment. It is also possible for you to open another account even at another bank if you don't want to pay a stop order. SASSA grant recipients can't do any of this. This is about the ethics of charging high interest for low risk business. This is very low risk business.

Comment: Don't know that it would work today.  

It certainly worked 60 years ago. (I live in a province that was, essentially, built during that era: BC.)

 Sixty years ago, outside of labour unions, the only people who protested publicly were a few "kooks" and "beatniks." And most of the signs they waved simply said, "ban the bomb."

Today, there are major protests almost every week and the placards read everything you can imagine and more. It's a different "rights and freedoms" world, C Parsons, than it was in those "lets roll up our sleeves and go to work" postwar development era.  

What spurred America on in the late 50s in one area (space) was being beaten by Russia. National pride was at stake. Canada's reaction would have been, "Oh, well, let 'em go to it. If--big if--we want space development, we'll buy it from them later."

Comment: The ACHA does not have flaws that can be fixed; it's a piece of garbage that must be trashed, and will be. To the extent that the bishops bought into the notion that "pro-life" reduces to anti-abortion, to that extent they share responsibility for the bill they are now criticizing. Trump and the House Republicans are relentless, militantly anti-life and pro-sickness, pro-death.
The ACHA is not a health care bill at all; it's a tax cut bill, part of the larger Trump project, the only one that really matters to him, to cut taxes for the wealthiest Americans and to pay for them (to the extent that he pays for them at all) by taking health care away from millions of Americans.
Donald Trump has demonstrated repeatedly that he doesn't know anything about health care and that he doesn't care about it -- or about the millions of people he will hurt in order to reduce his own taxes.

Comment: Hey Gary, thanks for asking!  Actually   I threw that Russian  in   as  humor, as an attention getter,  glad you caught it.  Well, I was kind of hoping someone someone in our electronic community would pick up on it...But not so many people know Russian  these days as did back in the Cold War when we took Russians seriously and the army taught a lot of us GIs Russian.

These  are the opening lines to one of Russia's greatest patriotic songs, "Borodino", celebrating the great battle of 1812 fought there against Napoleon:

"Oh, tell me old man, was it in vain that Moscow burned to ashes and surrendered to the French?"

All of us  who love old Russia are glad to see them recovering their pride in their culture but wish it could be done in a democratic fashion and without the intense paranoia  and  hostility toward the rest of the world (not that they don't have multiple historic reasons to fear the Outside world.)  This  is also part of the legacy of Stalinism.

Cheers Gary, Doug.
.

Comment: All levels of government bailing out of affordable housing programs over the last 30 years are part of the problem, but a hugely underestimated factor is vacation rentals.  Three people I know have converted their rentals into vacation rentals because they can easily get triple to quadruple what they would get for month to month rent from a local tenant.  My tenant approached me about voluntarily increasing his rent since he sees what extortionate rents are going for in this neighborhood and he's worried.   And I suppose it's tempting when instead of getting his $975 per month I could be getting $2400.  On the other hand, he's been a great tenant for 6 years and I feel I owe him my loyalty in return for his.  After all, we have to ask ourselves what kind of city we want to live in? Become like Venice where no locals can even afford to live?  I don't want to contribute to that kind of city.
